reasoning: The comment accurately explains the mistake made by the player, as it highlights the strategic value of the knight and suggests better moves to preserve it.

comment: This is a hard position for black, but it's not time to throw away pieces yet. When in doubt, improve your worst pieces. Black would like to get his a-rook into the game. comment: So in conclusion, don't give up pieces for pawns except for VERY good reasons (like forced checkmate). Also, when in doubt in what to move, improve your worst pieces. Masters do this themselves when a plan isn't obvious. In addition, try to concentrate your heavy pieces (rooks & queen) on open files (columns)...they are most effective in that setup. Try to look at forced moves, and try ask yourself, "Why did my opponent move there?". If you ask yourself that question, often you can see that he was trying to threaten your pawns/pieces or checkmate, and if you see his threat, you can parry it.
reasoning: The comment thoroughly explains the mistake made by the player by addressing the context of the decision, providing strategic insights for improvement, and analyzing the opponent's potential intentions.

context: This is a game between W21 (as White) and B21 (as Black). Last move played: White plays Queen to g8 with check
reformulated: White's move to g8 for their queen was a poor decision. It's a critical moment to avoid sacrificing key pieces like pawns unless there's a clear, powerful reason, such as an inevitable checkmate. When unsure, focus on enhancing the least effective pieces in your position. Grandmasters often employ this strategy when the correct move isn't immediately apparent. Concentrating your more powerful pieces, such as rooks and the queen, on open files is a strategic advantage. Pay attention to your opponent's moves to understand their intentions. If you consider why your opponent chose to make that move, it can reveal their strategy to attack your pieces or set up a checkmate, allowing you to counteract effectively.
